channel.title: Wtf
channel.description:
So, saw this thread on MITB, but it was locked.
48÷2(9+3)=?????
Does that mean:
48÷[2(9+3)]=
or
(48÷2)(9+3)=
or something else?
.. because without parentheses or brackets, the whole thing seems ambiguous to me..

item.title: Wtf
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:80, topic:390890”][quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=486838.msg3571095#msg3571095 date=1303060975]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=486838.msg3571085#msg3571085 date=1303060495]

I say we stop talking about arithmetic now.

Btw, David, what math course do you take now atm?
[/quote]Calculus

Ik, I meant which one.
[/quote]My course is ‘Calculus’. I took trig/pre-calc last year though, if that helps[/quote]
Oh, so like basic calculus I guess? Idk. The first year I took calc, we did L’Hopital’s Rule, etc. Did you?

Read full topic

item.title: Wtf
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I agree, I think it’s 288 (which is what I posted on MITB a few days ago). But Evil_ showed an interesting article to me saying something about positioning, where some people think a(x + b) = (a(x+b)) because they think xb = (x * b)

In a few years, it could very well change that position does influence OOO

Read full topic

item.title: Wtf
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

Davidi2:

^ It’s all interpretation, if you say that xy = (x * y), then it’s 2. Otherwise, it’s 288

I was wrong. It’s 288 if you go with PEMDAS.

Read full topic

item.title: Wtf
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

Fuck me. Everyone that the says the answer is 2 are idiots.

The answer is 288. Now fuck off trying to say it’s 2… because it’s not.

Read full topic

item.title: Wtf
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“John459, post:71, topic:390890”][quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=486838.msg3569429#msg3569429 date=1302921802]

When you have a bunch of operations of the same rank, you just operate from left to right. For instance, 15 ÷ 3 × 4 is not 15 ÷ 12, but is rather 5 × 4, because, going from left to right, you get to the division first.

I was just being an idiot, sorry for that. Funny how a calculus student can’t do arithmetic. :S
[/quote]It tends to be that as you go into higher mathmatics, you forget older things

For example, I was taking calculus last semester, and we had a state test (grade 10) on grade 10 stuff, which is geometry. I didn’t do very well on it because I had forgotten many of the geometry things from 2 years ago

That’s true, especially for geometry. I hated geometry anyways, even though I had straight 100 averages in all my math classes thus far.

I’d rather be arguing over calculus than arithmetic, as it’s SOOO much more interesting…

Math itself isn’t interesting. It gets interesting when you apply the math you’ve learned in things like physics.[/quote]
Very true. Calculus can be interesting too though. Well, physics uses calculus. I guess both math and science are awesome?

Read full topic

item.title: Wtf
item.dc:creator: @Slave_Scyth Slave Scyth
item.description:
@Slave_Scyth wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:61, topic:390890”][quote author=ytuio9 link=topic=486838.msg3569218#msg3569218 date=1302912365]

That’s pretty much the same problem, just different numbers and without the bracketed numbers.

Exactly. You also have to think of the original equation like this:

48 / 18 + 6

which results in 2 (48 / 24)

The original equation could have just factored 2 from the right side of the / sign.

I don’t understand.

48 / 24
48 / 18 + 6
48 / (18 / 2) + (6 / 2)
48 / 2(9 + 3)

That’s assuming the original equation is 48 / 18 + 6.

You could also do
48 / 6(3 + 1)

But 48 / 24 is not the same is 48 / 18 + 6 o.o
[/quote]

Yes, I forgot the parentheses around the 18 + 6. It’s possible that the original equation is 48 / (18 + 6), and someone factored out 2, resulting in 2(9 + 3), or if they had factored out 6, it would be 6(3 + 1). We’ll probably never know. If the equation designated parentheses around the 2(9 + 3), then it would without a doubt be 2. It’s generally understood that when dealing with parenthesis, multiplication is (sort of) included, or implied multiplication.

Both can be completely valid answers, it just depends on how you interpret it.[/quote]You literally just said “math is subjective”; dumbest thing I think I’ve ever seen anyone say/type.

You don’t factor when you can combine terms still, first off. That goes with the “solve parentheses” part of PEMDAS/whatever other acronyms there are. Then you read from left-to-right.

NONE of this, none of math at all, is subjective (that’s the goal of math). The answer is 288.

Read full topic

item.title: Wtf
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:61, topic:390890”][quote author=ytuio9 link=topic=486838.msg3569218#msg3569218 date=1302912365]
But 48 / 24 is not the same is 48 / 18 + 6 o.o
[/quote]
Yes, I forgot the parentheses around the 18 + 6. It’s possible that the original equation is 48 / (18 + 6), and someone factored out 2, resulting in 2(9 + 3), or if they had factored out 6, it would be 6(3 + 1). We’ll probably never know. If the equation designated parentheses around the 2(9 + 3), then it would without a doubt be 2. It’s generally understood that when dealing with parenthesis, multiplication is (sort of) included, or implied multiplication.

Both can be completely valid answers, it just depends on how you interpret it.[/quote]
But…
48 / 24
48 / (18 + 6)
48 / (2(9 + 3))

Still have to do parenthesis first which would lead you back to the first equation, right?

Read full topic

item.title: Wtf
item.dc:creator: @Slave_Scyth Slave Scyth
item.description:
@Slave_Scyth wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:49, topic:390890”][quote author=durial12 link=topic=486838.msg3569158#msg3569158 date=1302909262]

Wiki:

The standard order of operations, or precedence, is expressed in the following chart.

terms inside brackets
exponents and roots
multiplication and division
addition and subtraction[/quote]

Terms inside brackets suggests that the 2 should be dealt as a multiplication, not part of the bracket.

I understand that, but

x÷y(z) could be

x x
----- or ---- * z
y(z) y[/quote]No, it couldn’t.

The first one is 48 / (2*(9+3))

It is the second one, though. (Which contradicts yourself, considering those 2 equations were not the same.)

x = 48
y = 2
z = (9 + 3)

It’s left-to-right; simple as that. I don’t see how you guys are possibly arguing about this.

The answer is 288.

Read full topic

item.title: Wtf
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“ytuio9, post:60, topic:390890”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=486838.msg3569213#msg3569213 date=1302912110]

That’s pretty much the same problem, just different numbers and without the bracketed numbers.

Exactly. You also have to think of the original equation like this:

48 / 18 + 6

which results in 2 (48 / 24)

The original equation could have just factored 2 from the right side of the / sign.

I don’t understand.

48 / 24
48 / 18 + 6
48 / (18 / 2) + (6 / 2)
48 / 2(9 + 3)

That’s assuming the original equation is 48 / 18 + 6.

You could also do
48 / 6(3 + 1)
[/quote]
But 48 / 24 is not the same is 48 / 18 + 6 o.o[/quote]

Yes, I forgot the parentheses around the 18 + 6. It’s possible that the original equation is 48 / (18 + 6), and someone factored out 2, resulting in 2(9 + 3), or if they had factored out 6, it would be 6(3 + 1). We’ll probably never know. If the equation designated parentheses around the 2(9 + 3), then it would without a doubt be 2. It’s generally understood that when dealing with parenthesis, multiplication is (sort of) included, or implied multiplication.

Both can be completely valid answers, it just depends on how you interpret it.

Read full topic
